Chapter.Section:
Wedderburn decomposition
a list of simple algebras
The input FG should be a group algebra of a finite group G over the field F, where F is either the field of characteristic zero or a finite field of characteristic coprime with the order of G.
In the case of characteristic zero, the function returns the list of all Wedderburn components () of the group algebra FG.
In the case of non-zero characteristic, it returns a list of Wedderburn components of FG realizable by strongly Shoda pairs (see ) of the group G. If not all Wedderburn components of FG can be realizable by strongly Shoda pairs, a warning will be displayed. For many groups G every Wedderburn component of FG is realizable by a strongly Shoda pair and then the direct product of the entries of the output is isomorphic to FG. For example this is the case if G is abelian-by-supersolvable .
gap> WedderburnDecomposition( GroupRing( GF(5), DihedralGroup(16) ) ); [ GF(5), GF(5), GF(5), GF(5), ( GF(5)^[ 2, 2 ] ), ( GF(5^2)^[ 2, 2 ] ) ] # OLD gap> WedderburnDecomposition( GroupRing( GF(5), DihedralGroup(16) ) ); [ ( GF(5)^[ 1, 1 ] ), ( GF(5)^[ 1, 1 ] ), ( GF(5)^[ 1, 1 ] ), ( GF(5)^[ 1, 1 ] ), ( GF(5)^[ 2, 2 ] ), ( GF(5^2)^[ 2, 2 ] ) ] # NEW!!!
The previous example shows that the Wedderburn decomposition of the group algebra GF(5) D_{16} of the dihedral group of order 16 over the field of order 5 is 4 GF(5) \oplus M_2(GF(5)) \oplus M_2(GF(25)).
Next example shows the Wedderburn decomposition of the rational group algebra of the symmetric group on 4 letters.
gap> WedderburnDecomposition( GroupRing( Rationals, SymmetricGroup(4) ) ); [ Rationals, Rationals, ( Rationals^[ 3, 3 ] ), ( Rationals^[ 3, 3 ] ), <crossed product over CF(3), with 2 generators and center=Rationals> ]
If not all the Wedderburn components of the input are realizable by strongly Shoda pairs, a warning message is displayed together with the output, like in the following example for the smallest group with a monomial but non-strongly monomial irreducible character:
gap> WedderburnDecomposition( GroupRing( GF(5), SmallGroup(48,28) ) ); [ ( GF(5)^[ 1, 1 ] ), ( GF(5)^[ 1, 1 ] ), ( GF(5)^[ 2, 2 ] ), ( GF(5^2)^[ 2, 2 ] ), ( GF(5)^[ 3, 3 ] ), ( GF(5)^[ 3, 3 ] ), ( GF(5)^[ 4, 4 ] ) ] # NEW!!!
Nevertheless, we are able to give the full Wedderburn decomposition for group algebras of the same group in characteristic zero, for example:
gap> WedderburnDecomposition( GroupRing( Rationals, SmallGroup(48,28) ) ); [ Rationals, Rationals, ( Rationals^[ 3, 3 ] ), ( Rationals^[ 3, 3 ] ), <crossed product over CF(3), with 2 generators and center=Rationals>, <crossed product over AsField( NF(8,[ 1, 7 ]), CF(8) ), with 2 generators and center=NF(8,[ 1, 7 ])>, ( <crossed product over CF(3), with 2 generators and center=Rationals>^ [ 1, 1 ] ) ] # OLD!!! gap> WedderburnDecomposition( GroupRing( Rationals, SmallGroup(48,28) ) ); [ Rationals, Rationals, ( Rationals^[ 3, 3 ] ), ( Rationals^[ 3, 3 ] ), <crossed product over CF(3), with 2 generators and center=Rationals>, <crossed product over AsField( NF(8,[ 1, 7 ]), CF(8) ), with 2 generators and center=NF(8,[ 1, 7 ])>, ( <crossed product over CF(3), with 2 generators and center=Rationals>^ [ 2, 2 ] ) ] # NEW !!! gap> WedderburnDecomposition( GroupRing( CF(3), SmallGroup(48,28) ) ); [ CF(3), CF(3), ( CF(3)^[ 3, 3 ] ), ( CF(3)^[ 3, 3 ] ), ( CF(3)^[ 2, 2 ] ), <crossed product over AsField( NF(24,[ 1, 7 ]), CF(24) ), with 2 generators and center=NF(24,[ 1, 7 ])>, ( CF(3)^[ 4, 4 ] ) ]
a list of numerical descriptions of simple algebras
This function is a counterpart of which uses the same group algebra FG as an input and computes some numerical data describing the Wedderburn components (see ) of the group algebra FG with the same limitations in the case of non-zero characteristic as in . See for further interpretation of the output.
gap> F:=FreeGroup("a","b");;a:=F.1;;b:=F.2;;rel:=[a^8,a^4*b^2,b^-1*a*b*a];; gap> Q16:=F/rel;; QQ16:=GroupRing( Rationals, Q16 );; gap> QS4:=GroupRing( Rationals, SymmetricGroup(4) );; gap> WedderburnDecomposition(QQ16); [ Rationals, Rationals, Rationals, Rationals, ( Rationals^[ 2, 2 ] ), <crossed product over AsField( NF(8,[ 1, 7 ]), CF(8) ), with 2 generators and center=NF(8,[ 1, 7 ])> ] gap> WedderburnDecomposition( QS4 ); [ Rationals, Rationals, ( Rationals^[ 3, 3 ] ), ( Rationals^[ 3, 3 ] ), <crossed product over CF(3), with 2 generators and center=Rationals> ] gap> WedderburnDecompositionInfo(QQ16); [ [ 1, Rationals ], [ 1, Rationals ], [ 1, Rationals ], [ 1, Rationals ], [ 2, Rationals ], [ 1, NF(8,[ 1, 7 ]), 8, [ 2, 7, 4 ] ] ] gap> WedderburnDecompositionInfo(QS4); [ [ 1, Rationals ], [ 1, Rationals ], [ 3, Rationals ], [ 3, Rationals ], [ 1, Rationals, 3, [ 2, 2, 0 ] ] ]
In the previous example we computed the Wedderburn decomposition of the rational group algebra QQ_{16} of the quaternion group of order 16 and the rational group algebra QS_{4} of the symmetric group on four letters. For both group algebras we used both and .
The output shows that
QQ_{16} = 4 \Q \oplus M_2(\Q) \oplus A
QS_{4} = 2Q \oplus 2 M_2(\Q) \oplus B
where A and B are crossed products with coefficients in the cyclotomic fields CF(8) and CF(3) respectively. This output can be used as a &GAP; object, but it does not give clear information on the structure of algebras A and B.
Instead the numerical information displayed by means that
A = Q(\xi|\xi^8=1)[g | \xi^g = \xi^7 = \xi^{-1}, g^2 = \xi^4 = -1]
B = Q(\xi|\xi^3=1)[g | \xi^g = \xi^2 = \xi^{-1}, g^2 = 1]
Both A and B are quaternion algebras over its centre which is Q(\xi+\xi^{-1}) and the former is equal to Q(\sqrt{2}) and Q respectively.
In B, one has (g+1)(g-1)=0, while g is neither 1 nor -1. This shows that B=M_2(Q). However the relation g^2=-1 in A shows that
A=Q(\sqrt{2})[i,g|i^2=g^2=-1,ig=-gi]
and so A is a division algebra with centre Q(\sqrt{2}), which is a subalgebra of the algebra of Hamiltonian quaternions.
In the next example we show the output of WedderburnDecompositionInfo for SmallGroup(48,28). You can compare it with the output of for the same group in the previous section.
gap> WedderburnDecompositionInfo( GroupRing( Rationals, SmallGroup(48,28) ) ); [ [ 1, Rationals ], [ 1, Rationals ], [ 3, Rationals ], [ 3, Rationals ], [ 1, Rationals, 3, [ 2, 2, 0 ] ], [ 1, NF(8,[ 1, 7 ]), 8, [ 2, 7, 4 ] ], [ 2, Rationals, 6, [ 2, 5, 3 ] ] ] gap> WedderburnDecompositionInfo( GroupRing( CF(3), SmallGroup(48,28) ) ); [ [ 1, CF(3) ], [ 1, CF(3) ], [ 3, CF(3) ], [ 3, CF(3) ], [ 2, CF(3), 3, [ 1, 1, 0 ] ], [ 1, NF(24,[ 1, 7 ]), 8, [ 2, 7, 4 ] ], [ 4, CF(3), 6, [ 1, 1, 0 ] ] ]

ManSection.Description:
The three-input versions computes the Wedderburn component () of the rational group algebra QG of a finite group G realized by a strongly Shoda pair (K,H) of G (see Section ).
The four-input versions computes the Wedderburn component of the semisimple finite group algebra FG realized by a strongly Shoda pair (K,H) of G and a generating q-cyclotomic class modulo [K:H] (see Section ). The cyclotomic class can be given either by the cyclotomic class itself or by a representative, that is an integer coprime with [K:H].
The versions ended in NC does not check if (K,H) is a strongly Shoda pair of G and, in the four-input version, if C is either a generating q-cyclotomic class C modulo [K:H] or an integer coprime with [K:H].

ManSection.Description:
The three-input versions computes the numerical information describing the Wedderburn component () of the rational group algebra QG of a finite group G realized by a strongly Shoda pair (K,H) of G (see Section ).
The four-input versions computes a pair [n,q] of positive integers with q a prime power describing the Wedderburn component of the semisimple finite group algebra FG realized by a strongly Shoda pair (K,H) of G and a generating q-cyclotomic class C modulo [K:H] as the n by n matrix algebra over GF(q) (see Section ).
The fourth input can be given either as a cyclotomic class or as its representative.
The versions ended in NC does not check if (K,H) is a strongly Shoda pair of G, and, in the four-input version, if C is a generating q-cyclotomic class C modulo [K:H] or an integer coprime with [K:H].
